greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest integer with exactly n semiprime divisors.
comment: On the suggestion in A086971 by Zak Seidov, Mar 31 2011.
Often a(n+1) = k*a(n) for some integer k.
All members are cubefree products of primorials (A025487 INTERSECT A004709). - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 11 2012
A086971(a(n)) = n and A086971(m) != n for m < a(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 14 2012
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
mathematica: semiPrimeQ[n_] := PrimeOmega@ n == 2; f[n_] := Length@ Select[Divisors@ n, semiPrimeQ@# &]; t = Table[0, {50}]; k = 1; While[k < 10^7, a = f@ k; If[t[[a]] == 0, t[[a]] = k; Print[{a, k}]]; k++]; t
program: a220264 n = fromJust $ find ((== n) . a086971) a220423_list
results.author: _Robert G. Wilson v_, Dec 09 2012
ext: a(27)-a(41) from _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Dec 11 2012
